triples.name: Control theory
triples.relevance: Control theory provides the foundational mathematical frameworks for designing and analyzing systems used in networked system control applications.

triples.name: Filter (signal processing)
triples.relevance: Signal filtering is a key technique reviewed in the survey for processing and managing data in networked systems.

triples.name: Networked control system
triples.relevance: Networked control systems are the primary focus of this survey, examining how control loops are closed through communication networks.

triples.name: Communication protocol
triples.relevance: Communication protocols are central to the survey as they define the rules and structure for data transmission in networked systems.

triples.name: Stability theory
triples.relevance: Stability analysis is extensively reviewed in the survey as a key problem in protocol-based control of networked systems.

triples.name: Scheduling (computing)
triples.relevance: Protocol scheduling is a central issue in the survey, addressing how communication resources are allocated in networked systems.

triples.name: Fault detection and isolation
triples.relevance: The survey provides a systematic review of communication-protocol-based fault diagnosis problems in networked systems.

triples.name: Time-variant system
triples.relevance: Time-varying nature of networked systems is identified as a key characteristic that affects protocol-based analysis and synthesis.

triples.name: Distributed computing
triples.relevance: Distributed structure is one of the key characteristics of networked systems discussed in the survey.

triples.name: Uncertainty quantification
triples.relevance: Parameter uncertainties are identified as a critical aspect of networked systems requiring protocol-based control and filtering strategies.
